content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a risk-averse person who values security, I would tend to choose the option that ensures a consistent and relatively high payoff over the long term. In this game, if both players consistently pick B, we each earn 40$ per round for a total of 3000$ (75 rounds * 40$). This is higher than the 3150$ I would earn if I chose R and the other player picked B for all 75 rounds. However, since this is an anonymous game with an unknown opponent, there's a chance that my opponent might not be as risk-averse as I am and might choose R in some or even many of the rounds.

Given that the payoff is higher when we both pick B (40$) than when I pick R and the other picks B (35$), it seems logical to choose B to maximize my potential earnings, especially considering that there are 75 rounds. However, if I observe a pattern in my opponent's choices and see they consistently pick R, I might adjust my strategy accordingly to maximize my payoff. In any case, I will make the decision based on the information available at each round, knowing that this is a game with many rounds and the potential for a higher payoff lies in consistency rather than taking risks. {B}

Since my strategy has been to choose B whenever possible, but now I got a different outcome from my opponent, I will reassess my strategy and consider the potential for maximizing my payoff in the long run. In this situation, if I continue choosing B while my opponent chooses R, I will earn 35$ per round, and they will get 0$. However, if I switch my strategy to choose R in response to my opponent's choice of R, then we both will get 45$ per round.

Considering the long-term payoff potential, it seems that switching strategies could lead to a higher payoff over the 75 rounds. In this case, I will switch my strategy and choose R for the next round. {R}
